subject: RE: [junit] Re: performance testing
msgSnippet: There s a tool called Enhanced Junit (http://www.javatesting.com/Product/enhancedjunit) that, besides enabling you to distribute tests across multiple threads,
messageBody:
There's a tool called Enhanced Junit
(http://www.javatesting.com/Product/enhancedjunit) that, besides
enabling you to distribute tests across multiple threads, VMs and
machines for load testing provides some APIs for fine-grained execution
timing within your test. They are intended to be used within load tests
but you can use them anywhere.

The execution timer API is:

// Start the timer.
void start()

// Return the current accumulated time in milliseconds. This does not
effect the current accumulated time. long checkpoint()

// Return the current accumulated time in milliseconds and cease
accumulating time. long pause()

// Resume accumulating time
void resume()

// Return the current accumulated time in milliseconds and cease
accumulating time.
// This simply calls pause(), however it is useful if your intention is
to
// communicate to the reader of the code that you are done timing.
long end()

// Reset accumulated time to zero and cease accumulating additional time
void reset()

// Assert that the current execution time is outside of (greater than) a
specified
void assertTimeOutsideOfBoundary(
String message,
long boundary)

// Assert that the current execution time is within (less than or equal
to) a specified boundary time void assertTimeWithinBoundary(
String message,
long boundary)

// Assert that the current execution time is within specified start and
end boundary times: // startBoundary <= time <= endBoundary void
assertTimeWithinBounds(
String message,
long startBoundary,
long endBoundary)

-----------------------------
Mike Silverstein
SilverMark, Inc.
The Object Testing Company
www.javatesting.com

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Chad Woolley [mailto:lists@...]
> Sent: Thursday, November 13, 2003 1:10 PM
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Re: performance testing
>
>
> This is a situation where Aspect-Oriented Programming might be useful
> after all.
>
> This might be caused because the framework is doing some
> "Other Stuff"
> which is getting in the way of timing the actual execution
> time of the
> real work. It may not be easy to extend the framework to get your
> numbers and still get "close enough" to the actual test
> execution to get
> meaningful numbers.
>
> It might turn out that the test fixture setup is obscuring the actual
> execution time of the tests. FOr example, if the fixture setup takes
> much longer than the actual execution of the Class Under Test. This
> would make it difficult to get meaningful numbers, since the
> variance in
> the fixture execution time would obscure the actual test performance
> numbers.
>
> In this situation, you could come up with some scheme to wrap the
> monitoring around the actual call to your Class Under Test, and avoid
> including your fixture setup in the monitoring.
>
> AOP could be well suited for this type of task, because otherwise you
> would have to duplicate this monitoring code (or at least remember to
> duplicate a call to it) in each test method.
>
> Then again, there could be a way to accomplish the same thing
> with Plain
> Old Java. Maybe by routing all calls to the Class Under Test
> through a
> monitoring method. This could take the class name, method
> name, and any
> params, then use some fancy reflection to invoke the method
> and gather
> the elapsed time.
>
> -- Chad
>
> Jim Dixon wrote:
> > I haven't done very careful testing, but I certainly have
> noticed that
> > the times reported by JUnit vary a great deal.
> >
> > Running one simple set of tests just now gave me results in
> which 50%
> > differences were common and more than one test took 3x as long from
> > one run to the next. So, sure, you can use JUnit for this sort of
> > simple performance testing, but you should at least run the tests
> > enough times to build statistical confidence in the results.
> >
> > It didn't show up in these few runs, but I believe that I
> have noticed
> > before that the first test reported a much longer than
> normal time --
> > seconds rather than milliseconds. So the order in which
> tests are run
> > might introduce an effect large enough to render the
> results useless.
>
>
>
>
